# Table of Contents

# 1. An Introduction to Cryptography

## 1.2 Divisibility and greatest common divisors

> **Definition.** Let $a, b \in \mathbb Z$ and $a \neq 0$.
> Then $a \mid b$ ("$a$ divides $b$"), if there exists $q \in \mathbb Z$ s.t.
>
> $$
> q \cdot a = b
> $$

> **Proposition 1.4** Let $a, b, c \in \mathbb Z$
>
> - If $a \mid b$ and $b \mid c$ $\implies$ $a \mid c$
> - If $a \mid b$ and $b \mid a$ $\implies$ $a = \pm b$
> - If $a \mid b$ and $a \mid c$ $\implies$ $a \mid (a + c)$ and $a \mid (b - c)$

> **Definition.** The _greatest common divisor_ of $a$ and $b$ is the largest positive integer $d$ such that $d \mid a$ and $d \mid b$.

> **Definition.** (Euclidean Algoritm) Let $a, b \in \mathbb Z$. Then $a$ divided by $b$ has quotient $q$ and remainder $r$.
>
> $$
> a = bq + r \quad \text{with } 0 \leq r \lt b
> $$
>
> From this formula and proposition 1.4 we get
>
> $$
> \gcd(a, b) = \gcd(b, r)
> $$
>
> Continuing this process with $\gcd(b, r) = \gcd(r', r)$ we eventually arrive at $\gcd(s, 0) = s$ where $s = \gcd(a, b)$.

> **Theorem 1.11** (Extended Euclidean Algorithm). Let $a, b \in \mathbb N$. Then
>
> $$
> au + bv = \gcd(a, b) \;, \quad u, v \in \mathbb Z
> $$
>
> always has a solution.
>
> If $(u_0, v_0)$ is one solution, then every solution has the form
>
> $$
> u = u_0 + \frac {bk} {\gcd(a, b)}
> \quad \text{and} \quad
> v = v_0 + \frac {ak} {\gcd(a, b)}
> \quad \text{for some } k \in \mathbb Z
> $$

_Proof._

Substitute the remainder in each step of the Euclidean Algorithm into the equation of the next step
in order to arrive at the expression.

> **Definition.** Let $a, b \in \mathbb Z$. We say that $a$ and $b$ are _relatively prime_ or _coprime_ if $\gcd(a, b) = 1$.
>
> More generally, any equation
>
> $$
> Au + Bv = \gcd(A, B)
> $$
>
> can be reduced to the case of relatively prime numbers by dividing both sides by $\gcd(A, B)$.
>
> $$
> \frac A {\gcd(A, B)} u + \frac B {\gcd(A, B)} v = 1
> $$

## 1.3 Modular arithmetic

> **Definition.** Let $m \geq 1$ be an integer. We say that integers $a$ and $b$ are _congruent modulo m_ if their difference $a - b$ is divisible by $m$.
>
> $$
> a \equiv b \pmod m
> $$

> **Proposition 1.13.** Let $m \geq 1$ be an integer.
> \
> \
> **(a)** If $a_1 \equiv a_2 \pmod m$ and $b_1 \equiv b_2 \pmod m$, then
>
> - $a_1 \pm b_1 \equiv a_2 \pm b_2 \pmod m$
> - $a_1 \cdot b_1 \equiv a_2 \cdot b_2 \pmod m$
>
> \
> **(b)** Let $a \in \mathbb Z$. Then
>
> $$
> a \cdot b \equiv 1 \pmod m \quad \text{for some integer $b$} \iff \gcd(a, m) = 1
> $$

_Proof._

$\implies:$
Assume $g = \gcd(a, m) \neq 1$, then $g \mid a$ and $g \mid m$.
Now let $b \in \mathbb Z$, then $ab = mk + r$.
It follows that $g \mid (ab - mk)$ and thus $g \mid r$. But if $g \neq 1 \mid r$, then $r \neq 1$.

$\impliedby:$
Theorem 1.11 says that $ab + mk = \gcd(a, m) = 1$ has a solution for $b, k \in \mathbb Z$.
Because $ab - 1 = -mk$, $ab \equiv 1 \pmod m$.

> **Definition.** Numbers that have multiplicative inverses modulo $m$ are called _units_.
>
> $$
> \begin{aligned}
> (\mathbb Z / m \mathbb Z)^*
> &= \{a \in \mathbb Z / m \mathbb Z : \gcd(a, m) = 1\} \\
> &= \{a \in \mathbb Z / m \mathbb Z : a\text{ has an inverse modulo }m\}
> \end{aligned}
> $$
>
> The set $(\mathbb Z / m \mathbb Z)^*$ is called the _group of units modulo m_.
>
> If $a_1$ and $a_2$ are units, then so is $a_1 \cdot a_2$.
> On the other hand, if we add two units, we do not always get a unit.

> **Definition.** _Euler's phi function_ (or _Euler's totient function_) is the function $\Phi(m)$ defined by
>
> $$
> \Phi(m) = \#(\mathbb Z / m \mathbb Z) ^* = \# \{ 0 \leq a \lt m: \gcd(a, m) = 1\} \;.
> $$

### 1.3.1 Modular arithmetic and shift ciphers

_Encryption._

$$
c \equiv p + k \pmod {26}
$$

_Decryption._

$$
p \equiv c - k \pmod {26}
$$

### 1.3.2 The fast powering algorithm

$g^A \pmod N$ can be computed by a succession of squarings and multiplications by using the binary expansion of the exponent, $A = A_0 + A_1 \cdot 2^1 + \cdots + A_r \cdot 2^r$.

_Example 1.19._

$$
3^{128}
= 3^{2 + 2^3 + 2^4 + 2^6 + 2^7}
= 3^{2^1} + 3^{2^3} + 3^{2^4} + 3^{2^6} + 3^{2^7}
$$

**Running Time.**
It takes at most $2r$ multiplications mod $N$ ($r$ multiplications for computing the squares and $r$ multiplications when computing the final result).
Because $A \geq 2^r$, it takes at most $2\log_2(A)$ multiplications to compute $g^A$.
If $A \approx 2^{1000}$, this is about $2000$ multiplications.

## 1.4 Prime numbers, unique factorization, and finite fields

> **Definition.** An integer $p$ is called a _prime_ if $p \geq 1$ and if the only positive divisors are $1$ and $p$.

> **Proposition 1.20.** Let $p$ be a prime number that divides the product $ab$ of two integers.
> Then $p$ divides at least one of $a$ and $b$.
> More generally, if $p \mid a_1a_2\cdots a_n$, then $p$ divides at least one of the $a_i$.

_Proof._
Let $g = \gcd (a, p)$. Then $g \mid p$, so either $g = 1$ or $g = p$.
If $g = p$, then $p \mid a$ and we're done.
Otherwise if $g = 1$, then Theorem 1.11 says that we're able to find $u$, $v$ satisfying $au + pv = 1$.
Multiplying by $b$ gives

$$
abu + pbv = b
$$

Since $p \mid ab$ and $p \mid pbv$, $p$ divides the left-hand side and so $p \mid b$.

> **Theorem 1.21 (The Fundamental Theorem of Arithmetic).**
> Let $a \geq 2$ be an integer. Then $a$ can be factored as a product of prime numbers
>
> $$
> a =
> p_1^{e_1}
>  \cdot p_2^{e_2}
>  \cdot p_3^{e_3}
>  \cdots
>   p_r^{e_r}
>  \; .
> $$
>
> This factorization is unique.

_Proof._

A simple algorithm can be used to prove that every $a \geq 2$ can be factored into primes.
To prove uniqueness of the factorization, let
$a = p_1^{e_1} \cdot p_2^{e_2} \cdot p_3^{e_3} \cdots p_r^{e_r} = q_1^{f_1} \cdot q_2^{f_2} \cdot q_3^{f_3} \cdots q_r^{f_s}$
be two factorizations of $a$.

$p_1$ is a factor of $a$, so by Proposition 1.20, it must divide the product $\prod_{i=1}^s q_i^{f_i}$. Since $p_1$ is prime, it means that there is an $1 \leq i \leq s$ with $q_i = p_1$.

Now, since $p_1^{e_1}$ divides the product, $p_1$ must also appear with the same exponent. This process can be repeated to show that $r = s$ and $\prod_{i=1}^r p_i^{e_i} = \prod_{i=1}^s q_i^{f_i}$.

> **Definition.** The _order_ or _exponent_ of a prime $p$ in $a$ - $\text {ord} _p (a)$ - is given by the power of $p$ in the factorization of $a$.
>
> $$
> a = \prod _{p \text { prime}} p^{\text {ord} _p (a)}
> $$

> **Proposition 1.22.** Every element $a \neq 0$ in $\mathbb Z / p \mathbb Z$ has a multiplicative inverse for $p$ prime.
>
> $$
> ab = 1 \mod p
> $$
>
> We denote $b = a^{-1} \mod p$.

_Proof._ This follows directly from Proposition 1.13 b)

Using the Euclidean Algorithm we can compute $a^{-1}$ efficiently by solving

$$
au + pv = 1 \;.
$$

If follows that $u = a^{-1}$.

With Proposition 1.22 we get that $(\mathbb Z / p \mathbb Z)^* = \{1, 2, \ldots, p-1\}$.

> **Definition.** $\mathbb Z / p \mathbb Z$ is a _field_. A field is a _Ring_ with the additional property that every
> nonzero element has a multiplicative inverse.
> We write
> $\mathbb F_p = \mathbb Z / p \mathbb Z$
> for the finite field of $p$ elements and $\mathbb F_p^* = (\mathbb Z / p \mathbb Z)^*$
> for its group of units with $p - 1$ elements.
